questions.question: A javelin is thrown from ground level with an initial speed $u$ at an angle of $30^\circ$ above the horizontal and lands back at the same level, 25 m away from the thrower. Assuming no air resistance, determine the maximum height $h$ reached by the javelin above the ground. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A javelin is thrown from ground level at an angle of $30^\circ$ above the horizontal and reaches a maximum height of $3.6$ m above the ground before landing back at the same level. Assuming no air resistance and $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$, determine the horizontal range of the javelin.

A ball is kicked from the top of a 5.0 m high platform with an initial speed of 18 m/s and lands on the ground below. It travels 24 m horizontally from the base of the platform before hitting the ground. Neglect air resistance and take $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$. Determine the angle of projection above the horizontal.
questions.explanation: Solving the equations yields two possible angles: 9.3° and 68.9°. Both are mathematically valid, but 9.3° is the smaller angle.

questions.question: A football is kicked from ground level with an initial speed of 22 m/s at an angle of 40° above the horizontal. Assume no air resistance and take $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the time it takes for it to reach 4 m on the way down.

A soccer ball is kicked from ground level with an initial speed of 25 m/s at an angle of 35° above the horizontal. Assume no air resistance and take $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the time it takes for the ball to reach 3 m above the ground on the way up.
A projectile is launched from ground level and stays in the air for a total of 6.0 s before hitting the ground. How long did it take to reach its maximum height?
questions.explanation: For symmetric projectile motion, time to maximum height is half the total time of flight: $t_{up} = T/2 = 3.0$ s.

questions.question: A soccer ball is kicked at 20 m/s at an angle of 30° and reaches a certain horizontal range. At what other angle could the ball be kicked with the same speed to reach the same range?
questions.explanation: Complementary angles ($\theta$ and $90° - \theta$) give the same range. $90° - 30° = 60°$.

questions.question: Two projectiles, A and B, are launched with the same speed. A is launched at 15° and B is launched at 75°. Which statement is true regarding their flight?
options: Projectile B has a greater maximum height.
They reach the apex at the same time.
Projectile A stays in the air longer.
Projectile B has a greater range.
questions.explanation: $H \propto \sin^2\theta$. $\sin75° > \sin15°$, so B has greater height. They have the same range (complementary angles).

questions.question: A cannonball is fired at 30° and reaches its maximum height in 2.5 s. How much time passes between the launch and the ball being 10 m above the ground on its way down?
questions.explanation: Time to max height = 2.5 s, total time = 5.0 s. Time to 10 m on way down is > 2.5 s and < 5.0 s.

questions.question: What is the vertical displacement of a symmetric projectile when it is halfway through its total time of flight?
questions.explanation: Halfway through total time is at the apex, where vertical displacement equals maximum height H.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered complex projectile motion problems.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review how to set up equations for non-symmetric cases.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on using the quadratic formula for time.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how to break problems into components and apply kinematic equations.
